blocks.text: July 24, 1948 – At long last, a new car, a 1948 Dodge 4 Dr. Custom Sedan, the order for which was placed in March, 1946. This shows the tremendous backlog on new cars, a situation resulting from the war. The car cost $1,981, whereas virtually the same car in 1937 cost about $900. Gordon was allowed $160. on his old 1937 model. On the open market, immediately after purse chase from a manufacturer's dealer, this new car could have been sold for $2,600 to $2,700., so great is the demand.
Gymnasts performing in the school yard during August.

blocks.text: Just the stream for wading near Tucquan.
Ducks on parade

Tobacco is known
tobacco is rare. June and is the frost can curing in large packed for sale stripping over prices The buyers are being offered securing better

Tobacco is known as the "money" crop in Lancaster County, where more cigar tobacco is raised than anywhere else in the world. Tobacco is planted in June and is cut from the second week in August to late September, before the frost can damage the leaves. After cutting, the tobacco is hung for curing in large barns. From November to March the leaves are stripped and packed for sale. Whole families, including the children, engage in the stripping process. Generally in January, February and March the tug-of-war over prices is held between the buyers for the large firms and the farmers. The buyers visit the farms, and the word spreads quickly about prices that are being offered. Some farmers sell quickly and others hold on in the hope of securing better prices later on.

blocks.text:
The Conestoga Road
As early as 1638 an Indian trail,
used in the fur trade with the
Swedish Settlements on the Delaware.
crossed Conestoga Creek 400 feet
upstream.
Along the historic Conestoga Road from Rock Hill to Safe Harbor. The roadside markers have been erected by the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company.

IRON WORKS
In 1846 the Safe Harbor blast fur-
nace, foundry and rolling mill, using
anthracite for fuel, were built by
Reeves, Abbott & Co. Great quantities
of iron and rails were produced for
the Pennsylvania R.R., incorporated in
the same year. During the Civil War
wrought iron cannon were manu-
factured for the Union Army.
[Seal of a government body]

PORT OF LANCASTER
The Conestoga Navigation Co. (incd.1825)
constructed on Conestoga Creek, from
Lancaster to the Susquehanna River.
9 locks and dams which were used for
slackwater navigation for about 40 yrs.
A rock fill crib dam across the
river made possible cargo exchanges with
the Susquehanna and Tidewater
Canal-located on the west shore.
This is probably the ruins of the rolling mill which contained 13 furnaces and 16 boilers.
This mass of stone was the base of the furnace stack said to have been 45 feet high.

In 1846 the Safe Harbor blast fur-

of iron and rails were produced for

wrought iron cannon were manu-

blocks.text:
The Susquehannocks
THE most warlike of all Indian tribes lived along this river. Their power was broken in 1675 by a long war with the Five Nations, and the Maryland and Virginia colonies. Fortified towns were located near Turkey Hill and near Long Island. An Indian colony explored by the Pennsylvania Historical Commission and the Safe Harbor Water Power Corporation in 1930 recovered thousands of artifacts, now in the Pennsylvania State Museum at Harrisburg.
THE SUSQUEHANNOCKS
of artifacts, now State Museum a
The electrified Pennsylvania freight line, known as the "low grade", crosses the mouth of the Conestoga Creek. Here dwelt the warlike Susquehannocks.
The big, modern Safe Harbor Dam stretches across the Susquehanna just above the mouth of the Conestoga Creek.
The Susquehanna River below the Dam.
Power for the cities and towns.
( Camera data: no filter for signs; red filter for all other.

blocks.text: East Prospect

The Susquehanna River, whose origin is Lake Otsego in New York, winds its way for 448 miles through Pennsylvania and Maryland to tidewater. The River drains a watershed of 27,500 square miles, the largest basin of any of the rivers of North America flowing into the Atlantic Ocean south of the St. Lawrence.

These three graves are of people all of whom died before the Revolutionary War,

St. John's Churchyard are remarkably well preserved. The inscriptions are unique.
The one of Peter Bezallon reads: "Who ever thou art with tender Heart, Stop,Read,

blocks.text: January 8 to 14, 1949 - Business trip to Miami, Florida, with Kitty in accompaniment. Drove to Washington the evening of January 8; spent the night at Hotel Statler. Boarded an Eastern Air Lines DC-4 at 9:30 A. M., flew to Miami with only one stop at Palm Beach. As we flew over the General Oglethorpe near Savannah the hotel and swimming pool could be seen clearly. Reached Miami between 1 and 2 P. M. Return trip on January 14 in an Eastern Air Lines "Constellation"; flew at 300 miles per hour; one stop at Jacksonville; general flying altitude was 13,000 feet; return trip required a little more than four hours.
Over the Florida coast at 5,000 feet.
Waiting for our bags at Miami.

blocks.text: January, 1949
Kathy and Cindy stand before the fireplace wood stacked on our front porch.

Nancy and Kathy roller skating with Drew King and Johnny Stoekel. This will probably be recorded as one of the mildest winters in the records of Lancaster County. When these pictures were taken in late January, there had been only one real snow-fall of the season, that of December 19. In contrast, the western part of the country is experiencing the worst storms in its history.

blocks.text: A visit to Pool Forge, between Goodville and Churchtown, on the Conestoga Creek. The ironmasters house and buildings are remarkably well preserved. The forge was established at or before the time of the Revolutionary War by James Old, one of the early successful ironmasters of Pennsylvania. Old was a member of the Pennsylvania Legislature in 1791, 1792 and 1793. He married a daughter of Gabriel Davies, who is supposed to have owned the land on which Pool Forge was built. One of James Old's sons, William, married Elizabeth Stiegel, the daughter of Baron Stiegel; and a daughter, Ann, married Robert Coleman, one of Pennsylvania's foremost ironmasters. James Old helped to build Speedwell Forge on Hammer Creek, he owned Quatahpilla Forge near Lebanon, and had other interests in Chester, Lancaster and Berks counties. In 1795 he conveyed Pool Forge to his son, Davis. He died in 1809 and is buried in the graveyard of Bangor Church.

Fine Lancaster County farmhouse on route 772,
just north of Old Philadelphia Pike.

blocks.text: This fine old mansion, built in 1726, stands at the foot of Cherry Street, Columbia. It was built by John Wright who two years later procured a patent for a ferry across the river. This ferry became a part of the route from Philadelphia through Lancaster over which so many pioneers travelled seeking homes in the unexplored West. It is recorded that at times as many as two hundred vehicles were in line to be ferried across, and that people had to wait as much as two days for their turn to cross. During the Revolutionary War many settlers recrossed Wright's Ferry to seek safety on the Susquehanna's eastern shore. In 1777, after the members of the Continental Congress fled across the River to York, there was a strong movement to locate the national capitol here.
Covered bridge where Big and Little Chickies creeks meet. The bridge foundations in the foreground supported the old trolley line.
View from Chickies Hill in the direction of the Marietta Pike. The covered bridge at left can be seen right center.
A steam engine on the near Washingtonboro. railroad "low grade" railway road Washhingto tonbbbbb ororoo.
